article: What to Do When Discord Isn't Picking Up Your Voice: 20 Fixes
intro: Are you having trouble with Discord not picking up your voice when you're talking? This can be an incredibly frustrating situation, especially because there's not one single fix for the issue. However, we've gathered all the ways you can try and fix it when your mic just isn't working on Discord. Keep reading to learn more.

steps.title: Make sure you're not muted or deafened.
steps.subtitle: The first thing to check when Discord isn't picking up your mic is to make sure that you aren't muted or deafened. Simply look at the microphone (mute) or headphone (deafen) icons in Discord to see if they're active.
sub-points: You could have also gotten server muted or server deafened. If so, that can only be removed by a moderator or admin of the server you're in.

steps.title: Make sure you have the correct permissions to voice chat.
steps.subtitle: If you notice that only one server (or even just one voice channel) is giving you trouble with your microphone, it could be because you don't have the correct permissions for that channel.
sub-points: If you are able to edit permissions, right-click (or Ctrl-click on Mac, or long press on mobile) the channel and go to  > , then make sure your role has voice permissions.
If you can't edit the permissions for the server or channel, you'll need to ask an admin if they can adjust the permissions for you.

steps.title: Make sure your input sensitivity isn't set too low.Voice & VideoVoice
steps.subtitle: To get to your voice settings, click the cogwheel icon on desktop/the web or your profile picture on the app, then select  or just . In this menu, check your input sensitivity settings:
sub-points: Find  and toggle off "Automatically determine input sensitivity".

Then use the slider to adjust the ratio of green and yellow on the bar. The highlighted portion of this bar should always go into the green section when you're talking into your mic to ensure that everything you say is getting picked up.
If you don't want to turn off automatic input sensitivity, you can instead try toggling off  further down in the Voice & Video settings menu.

steps.title: Turn off noise suppression and automatic gain control.Voice & VideoVoice
steps.subtitle: To get to your voice settings, click the cogwheel icon on desktop/the web or your profile picture on the app, then select  or just . In this menu, check your input device:
sub-points: If you're having issues with your microphone not picking up your voice, turn off noise suppression. Discord has built-in noise suppression which usually works to cut out background noises when you're on a call, but it could be contributing to Discord not picking up your mic.
Toggle this off if you're having issues with Discord picking up your voice.

steps.title: Check the input settings on your actual microphone.
steps.subtitle: If you have a microphone where you can manually adjust the gain (such as a Blue Yeti), make sure your gain isn't turned down too low. If your gain is too low, your microphone may have a hard time picking up your voice.
sub-points: Also make sure your polar pattern is set to cardioid, if you have a cardioid microphone (like the Blue Yeti). The cardioid polar pattern icon looks like an upside-down, rounded heart.

steps.title: Make sure your mic is set up in the correct position for its polar pattern.
steps.subtitle: This only really applies if you've got a cardioid microphone. If you do, make sure you're talking into the front of the microphone. The mic shouldn't be angled towards you so you're talking into the top.
sub-points: Cardioid microphones pick up sound best when you're speaking into the front of them. Using a cardioid mic incorrectly could be contributing to why Discord isn't picking up your voice.

steps.title: Make sure the port your microphone is plugged into still works.
steps.subtitle: Try plugging your microphone into another USB port or microphone jack to see if this solves the problem. If your microphone has a USB plug, you can also try unplugging it from the port and plugging in something else, like a flash drive. If the flash drive appears in your devices and you can use it, then the issue isn't your USB port.
sub-points: If your microphone jack stops working, try a USB sound card. This device plugs into a USB port and has a headphone and microphone jacks so you can use your headphones/microphone via a USB port.

If you're running out of usable USB ports on your computer, try a USB hub. You just need one working USB port on your computer to plug the hub in, and then you can plug all of your USB devices into the hub to use them on your computer.

steps.title: Try running Discord as an administrator.
steps.subtitle: If your microphone is still not working, you can try running Discord as an administrator. This tip is only for Windows computers.
sub-points: With Discord closed, open it up by right-clicking Discord and selecting .
If certain games cause your microphone to stop working on Discord, make sure you run Discord as an administrator **before** you open the game.

steps.subtitle: While Discord's Quality of Service High Packet Priority setting usually makes voice calls smoother, it can sometimes cause the opposite to occur.
sub-points: To disable this setting, click the cogwheel icon on desktop/the web or your profile picture on the app, then select  or just . Then, scroll down and toggle off .

steps.title: Make sure your device is fully updated.
steps.subtitle: Whether you're on a PC, Mac, or mobile device, an outdated operating system can lead to a number of issues. If you have a pending OS update, download and install it before trying again.
sub-points: If you aren't sure how to update your device, you can read these wikiHow articles for , , , and .

steps.title: Your audio drivers may need an update.
steps.subtitle: This tip is for Windows only. While updating your Windows OS usually updates drivers as well, you may want to manually check for driver updates for thoroughness's sake. To update your drivers:
sub-points: Boot in Safe Mode, then right click the Start button and select Device Manager.
Expand .
Right click your microphone and select "Update driver". After the drivers have been updated, restart your PC to see if the issue still occurs.
